Dequantization of Real Algebraic Geometry
on Logarithmic Paper

Oleg Viro Department of Mathematics, Stony Brook University, NY 11794
oleg.viro@gmail.com
Abstract.

On logarithmic paper some real algebraic curves look like smoothed broken lines. Moreover, the broken lines can be obtained as limits of those curves. The corresponding deformation can be viewed as a quantization, in which the broken line is a classical object and the curves are quantum. This generalizes to a new connection between algebraic geometry and the geometry of polyhedra, which is more straight-forward than the other known connections and gives a new insight into constructions used in the topology of real algebraic varieties.

1. Graphs of polynomials on logarithmic paper

1.1. How to visualize a real polynomial?

If you ever tried to draw the graph for a polynomial of degree greater than, say, 4 and consisting of at least 4 monomials, you are aware of the natural difficulties. The graph is too steep. Whatever scale you choose, either some important details do not fit into the picture or are too small. The usual recipes from Calculus do not address the problem, but suggest, instead, to find roots of the first two derivatives, which does not seem to be much easier than the original problem.

1.2. Logarithmic paper

A physicist or engineer can give a more practical advice, based on their experience: use (double) logarithmic paper. This is a graph paper, called also log paper, with a non-uniform net of coordinate lines and logarithmic scales on both axes. On a log paper a point with coordinates xx, yy is shown at the position with the usual, Cartesian coordinates equal to lnxln⁡x, lnyln⁡y. In other words, the transition to the log paper corresponds to the change of coordinates:

{u=lnxv=lny.{u=ln⁡xv=ln⁡y.

On a log paper the first quadrant is expanded homeomorphically to the whole plane, the line x=1x=1 occupies the position of the axis of ordinates, the line y=1y=1 occupies the position of the axis of abscissas, the unit square bounded by these lines and the coordinate axes occupies the whole third quadrant.

1.3. A monomial on logarithmic paper

Let us try to follow the advice to use a log paper. Consider first the simplest special case: the graph of a monomial axkaxk (i. e., the curve defined by y=axky=axk). We are forced to consider only positive x,yx,y and hence assume aa to be positive as well. Then v=lny=ln(axk)=klnx+lna=ku+lna=ku+bv=ln⁡y=ln⁡(axk)=kln⁡x+ln⁡a=ku+ln⁡a=ku+b, where we denote lnaln⁡a by bb. Now the curve which we want to draw is defined in the coordinates uu and vv by the equation v=ku+bv=ku+b. Everybody knows that this is the straight line with slope kk meeting the axis of ordinates (i.e., vv-axis) at (0,b)(0,b).

1.4. Few slightly more complicated polynomials

First, consider a line y=1+xy=1+x. Then

v=lny=ln(1+x)=ln(1+eu).v=ln⁡y=ln⁡(1+x)=ln⁡(1+eu).

See the left plot in Figure 1, where the graph of v=ln(1+eu)v=ln⁡(1+eu) is shown together with lines v=0v=0 and v=uv=u, which represent on the log paper the monomials 1 and xx involved in our polynomial 1+x1+x. The graph of v=ln(1+eu)v=ln⁡(1+eu) looks like the broken line v=max{0,u}v=max{0,u} with a smoothed corner: it goes along and above of this broken line getting very close to it as |u||u| grows. For |u|>4|u|>4 the difference becomes beyond the resolution.

Here are two further examples: the quadratic polynomials 1+e±5x+x21+e±5x+x2. Then

v=ln(1+e±5x+x2)=ln(1+eu±5+e2u).v=ln⁡(1+e±5x+x2)=ln⁡(1+eu±5+e2u).

See the central and right plots in Figure 1. The graph of v=ln(1+eu±5+e2u)v=ln⁡(1+eu±5+e2u) looks like the broken line v=max{0,u±5,2u}v=max{0,u±5,2u} with smoothed corners. It goes along and above of this broken line getting very close to it far from its corners. Notice that the lines v=0v=0, v=u±5v=u±5 and v=2uv=2u represent on the logarithmic paper the monomials 1, e±5xe±5x and x2x2, respectively.

1.5. A polynomial versus the maximum of its monomials

This suggests, for a polynomial p(x)=anxn+an−1xn−1+⋯+a0p(x)=anxn+an−1xn−1+⋯+a0 with positive real coefficients ai=ebiai=ebi, to compare the graphs on log paper for pp and the maximum M(p)(x)=max{anxn,an−1xn−1,…,a0}M(p)(x)=max{anxn,an−1xn−1,…,a0} of its monomials. Denote the graph on log paper of a function ff by ΓfΓf. With respect to the usual Cartesian coordinates, ΓpΓp is the graph of

Lp(u)=ln(enu+bn+e(n−1)u+bn−1+⋯+eb0)Lp(u)=ln⁡(enu+bn+e(n−1)u+bn−1+⋯+eb0)

and ΓM(p)ΓM(p) is the graph of a piecewise linear convex function

Mp(u)=max{nu+bn, (n−1)u+bn−1, … , b0}.Mp(u)=max{nu+bn, (n−1)u+bn−1, … , b0}.

Obviously, Mp(u)≤Lp(u)≤Mp(u)+ln(n+1)Mp(u)≤Lp(u)≤Mp(u)+ln⁡(n+1). Hence ΓpΓp is above ΓM(p)ΓM(p), but below a copy of ΓM(p)ΓM(p) shifted upwards by ln(n+1)ln⁡(n+1). The latter is in fact a rough estimate. It turns to equality only at uu, where all linear functions, whose maximum is Mp(u)Mp(u), are equal: nu+bn=(n−1)u+bn−1=⋯=b0nu+bn=(n−1)u+bn−1=⋯=b0.

For a generic value of uu, only one of these functions is equal to Mp(u)Mp(u). Say Mp(u)=ku+bkMp(u)=ku+bk, while Mp(u)>d+lu+blMp(u)>d+lu+bl for some positive dd and each l≠kl≠k. Then

Lp(u)<Mp(u)+ln(1+ne−d)<Mp(u)+e−dn.Lp(u)<Mp(u)+ln⁡(1+ne−d)<Mp(u)+e−dn.

If for some value of uu the values of all of the functions ku+bkku+bk except two are smaller than Mp(u)−dMp(u)−d, then

Lp(u)<Mp(u)+ln(2+(n−1)e−d)<Mp(u)+ln2+e−d(n−1)/2.Lp(u)<Mp(u)+ln⁡(2+(n−1)e−d)<Mp(u)+ln⁡2+e−d(n−1)/2.

Thus, on a logarithmic paper the graph of a generic polynomial with positive coefficients lies in a narrow strip along the brocken line which is the graph of the maximum of its monomials. The width of the strip is estimated by characteristics of the mutual position of the lines which are the graphs of the monomials. The less congested the configuration of these lines, the norrower this strip.

1.6. Rescalings pushing the graph of a polynomial to a PL-graph

A natural way to make a configuration of lines less congested without changing its topology is to apply a dilation (u,v)↦(Cu,Cv)(u,v)↦(Cu,Cv) with a large C>0C>0. In what follows it is more convenient to use instead of CC a parameter hh related to CC by h=1/Ch=1/C. In terms of hh the dilation acts by (u,v)↦(u/h,v/h)(u,v)↦(u/h,v/h). It maps the graph of v=ku+bv=ku+b to the graph of v=ku+b/hv=ku+b/h. The parallel operation on monomials replaces axkaxk by a1/hxka1/hxk.

Consider the corresponding family of polynomials: ph(x)=∑ka1/hkxkph(x)=∑kak1/hxk. On log paper, the graphs of its monomials are obtained by dilation with ratio 1/h1/h from the graphs of the corresponding monomials of pp. Hence ΓM(ph)ΓM(ph) is the image of ΓM(p)ΓM(p) under the same dilation. However, ΓphΓph is not the image of ΓpΓp. It still lies in a strip along ΓM(ph)ΓM(ph) and the strip is getting narrower as hh decreases, but at the corners of ΓM(ph)ΓM(ph) the width of the strip cannot become smaller than ln2ln⁡2.

To keep the picture of our expanding configuration of lines (the graphs of monomials) independent on hh, let us make an additional calibration of coordinates: set uh=hu=hlnxuh=hu=hln⁡x, vh=hv=hlnyvh=hv=hln⁡y. Denote by ΓhfΓfh the graph of a function y=f(x)y=f(x) in the plane with coordinates uh,vhuh,vh.

Then ΓhM(ph)ΓM(ph)h does not depend on hh. The additional scaling reduces the width of the strip along ΓhM(ph)ΓM(ph)h, where ΓhphΓphh lies, forcing the width to tend to 0 as h→0h→0. Thus ΓhphΓphh tends to ΓhM(ph)ΓM(ph)h (in the C0C0 sense) as h→0h→0.

2. Quantization

2.1. Litvinov-Maslov dequantization of positive real numbers

The rescaling formulas uh=hlnxuh=hln⁡x, vh=hlnyvh=hln⁡y bring to mind formulas related to the Litvinov-Maslov dequantization of real numbers, see e.g. [4], [5]. The core of the Litvinov-Maslov dequantization is a family of semirings {Sh}h∈[0,∞){Sh}h∈[0,∞) (recall that a semiring is a sort of ring, but without subtraction). As a set, each of ShSh is ℝR. The semiring operations ⊕h⊕h and ⊙h⊙h in ShSh are defined as follows:

(1) a⊕hba⊕hb ={hln(ea/h+eb/h),max{a,b}, if h>0 if h=0={hln⁡(ea/h+eb/h), if h>0max{a,b}, if h=0
(2) a⊙hba⊙hb =a+b=a+b

These operations depend continuously on hh. For each h>0h>0 the map

Dh:ℝ+∖{0}→Sh:x↦hlnxDh:R+∖{0}→Sh:x↦hln⁡x

is a semiring isomorphism of {ℝ+∖{0},+,⋅}{R+∖{0},+,⋅} onto {Sh,⊕h,⊙h}{Sh,⊕h,⊙h}, that is

Dh(a+b)=Dh(a)⊕hDh(b),Dh(ab)=Dh(a)⊙hDh(b).Dh(a+b)=Dh(a)⊕hDh(b),Dh(ab)=Dh(a)⊙hDh(b).

Thus ShSh with h>0h>0 can be considered as a copy of ℝ+∖{0}R+∖{0} with the usual operations of addition and multiplication. On the other hand, S0S0 is a copy of ℝR where the operation of taking maximum is considered as an addition, and the usual addition, as a multiplication.

Applying the terminology of quantization to this deformation, we must call S0S0 a classical object, and ShSh with h≠0h≠0, quantum ones. The analogy with Quantum Mechanics motivated the following correspondence principle formulated by Litvinov and Maslov [4] as follows:

“There exists a (heuristic) correspondence, in the spirit of the correspondence principle in Quantum Mechanics, between important, useful and interesting constructions and results over the field of real (or complex) numbers (or the semiring of all nonnegative numbers) and similar constructions and results over idempotent semirings.”

This principle proved to be very fruitful in a number of situations, see [4], [5]. According to the correspondence principle, the idempotent counterpart of a polynomial

p(x)=anxn+an−1xn−1+⋯+a0p(x)=anxn+an−1xn−1+⋯+a0
is a convex PL-function
Mp(u)=max{nu+bn, (n−1)u+bn−1, … , b0}.Mp(u)=max{nu+bn, (n−1)u+bn−1, … , b0}.
As we have seen above, pp and MpMp are related not only on an heuristic level. In Section 1.6 we connected the graph ΓpΓp of pp on logarithmic paper and the graph ΓM(p)ΓM(p) of MpMp by a continuous family of graphs {Γhph}h∈(0,1){Γphh}h∈(0,1).

2.2. Logarithmic paper as a graphical device for the Litvinov-Maslov dequantization

As we saw in Section 1.5, the graph of a polynomial p(x)=∑kakxkp(x)=∑kakxk with positive real coefficients ak=ebkak=ebk on log paper is the graph of function ℝ→ℝR→R defined by v=ln(∑keku+bk)v=ln⁡(∑keku+bk). Observe that ln(∑keku+bk)ln⁡(∑keku+bk) is the value in S1S1 of the polynomial ∑kbkxk∑kbkxk at x=ux=u. Therefore we can identify the graph ΓpΓp of p(x)=∑kakxkp(x)=∑kakxk on log paper with the (Cartesian) graph of the polynomial ∑kbkxk∑kbkxk on S21S12.

Furthermore, ΓhphΓphh is the graph of the function ℝ→ℝR→R defined by

v=hln(∑ka1/hke(ku)/h)=hln(∑ke(ku+bk)/h).v=hln⁡(∑kak1/he(ku)/h)=hln⁡(∑ke(ku+bk)/h).

Observe, that the right hand side is the value in ShSh of the same polynomial ∑kbkxk∑kbkxk at uu. Therefore we can identify the graph ΓhphΓphh of ph(x)=∑ka1/hkxkph(x)=∑kak1/hxk on log paper with the (Cartesian) graph of ∑kbkxk∑kbkxk on S2hSh2.

At last, the graph of ∑kbkxk∑kbkxk on S20S02 is the the graph of MpMp.

We see that the whole job of deforming ΓpΓp to the graph of a piecewise linear convex function can be done by the Litvinov-Maslov dequantization: the deformation consists of the graphs of the same polynomial ∑kbkxk∑kbkxk on S2hSh2 for h∈[0,1]h∈[0,1]. The coefficients bkbk of this polynomial are logarithms of the coefficients of the original polynomial: bk=lnakbk=ln⁡ak. Since the map x↦lnx:ℝ+∖0→S1x↦ln⁡x:R+∖0→S1 was denoted above by D1D1, we denote by D1FD1F the polynomial obtained from a polynomial FF with positive coefficients by replacing its coefficients with their logarithms. Thus ∑kbkxk=D1p(x)∑kbkxk=D1p(x). Since D1D1 is a semiring homomorphism, the graph ΓpΓp of pp on log paper is the graph of D1pD1p on S21S12. The other graphs involved into the deformation are the graphs of the same polynomial D1pD1p on S2hSh2. They coincide with the graphs on log paper of the preimages phph of D1pD1p under DhDh. Indeed, ph(x)=∑ka1/hkxkph(x)=∑kak1/hxk and

D−1h(bk)=D−1hD1(ak)=eD1(ak)/h=e(lnak)/h=a1/hk.Dh−1(bk)=Dh−1D1(ak)=eD1(ak)/h=e(ln⁡ak)/h=ak1/h.

For a real polynomial p(x)=∑kakxkp(x)=∑kakxk with positive coefficients, we shall call ph(x)=∑ka1/hkxkph(x)=∑kak1/hxk with h>0h>0 the dequantizing family of polynomials.

2.3. Real algebraic geometry as quantized PL-geometry

The notion of polynomial is central in algebraic geometry. (I believe the subject of algebraic geometry would be better described by the name of polynomial geometry.) Since a polynomial over ℝR is presented so explicitly as a quantization of a piecewise linear convex function, one may expect to find along this line explicit relations between other objects and phenomena of algebraic geometry over ℝR and piecewise linear geometry. Indeed, in piecewise linear geometry the notion of piecewise linear convex function plays almost the same rôle as the notion of polynomial in algebraic geometry.

A representation of real algebraic geometry as a quantized PL-geometry may be rewarding in many ways. For example, in any quantization there are classical objects, i.e., objects which do not change much under the quantization. Objects of PL-geometry are easier to construct. If we knew conditions under which a PL object gives rise to a real algebraic object, which is classical with respect to the Litvinov-Maslov quantization, then we would have a simple way to construct real algebraic objects with controlled properties.

3. Algebraic geometry on logarithmic paper

3.1. Speak of real algebraic geometry only positively

Above in Section 1 we discussed the drawing of graphs on a logarithmic paper only for a polynomial with positive coefficients. The graphs allowed us to see the behavior of the polynomials only at positive values of the argument. This was for a good reason: we used logarithms of coordinates. The Litvinov-Maslov dequantization deals only with positive numbers. Therefore each fragment of algebraic geometry that we want to dequantize must be reformulated first only in terms of positive numbers. This seems to be possible for everything belonging to real algebraic geometry.

3.2. Visualizing roots of a polynomial on logarithmic paper

Above we could not encounter roots of polynomials, for a polynomial with positive coefficients has no positive roots. However if we really want to do algebraic geometry on log paper, we must figure out how to use graphs on log paper for visualizing roots (well, only positive roots) of an arbitrary real polynomial.

Any real polynomial p(x)p(x) is a difference p+(x)−p−(x)p+(x)−p−(x) of polynomials with positive coefficients. We can reformulate the problem of finding the positive roots of pp as the problem of finding positive values of xx at which p+(x)=p−(x)p+(x)=p−(x). The graphs of p+p+ and p−p− can be drawn on a log paper, where they are localized in the strips along broken lines, see Section 1.5 above. For some polynomials this picture gives a decent information on the number and position of the positive roots.

The negative roots of p(x)p(x) can be treated in the same way, since their absolute values are the positive roots of p(−x)p(−x).

3.3. Plane algebraic curves on logarithmic paper

Now consider a real polynomial p(x,y)=∑k,lak,lxkylp(x,y)=∑k,lak,lxkyl in two variables. Similarly to the case of polynomials in one variable, in the logarithmic space the graph of a monomial axkylaxkyl with a>0a>0 is a plane w=ku+lv+lnaw=ku+lv+ln⁡a, and the graph ΓpΓp of a polynomial p(x,y)p(x,y) with positive coefficients lies in a neighborhood of a convex piecewise linear surface, which is the graph ΓM(p)ΓM(p) of the maximum M(p)M(p) of the monomials. Furthermore, pp is included into a dequantizing family phph defined as ∑k,la1/hk,lxkyl∑k,lak,l1/hxkyl for h>0h>0, cf. Section 2.2. The graph ΓhphΓphh of phph in the logarithmic space with scaled coordinates uh=hlnxuh=hln⁡x, vh=hlnyvh=hln⁡y, wh=hlnzwh=hln⁡z coincides with the graph of the polynomial D1p(x,y)=∑k,l(lnak,l)xkylD1p(x,y)=∑k,l(ln⁡ak,l)xkyl in S3hSh3. These graphs with h∈(0,1]h∈(0,1] constitute a continuous deformation of Γp=Γ1p1Γp=Γp11 to ΓM(p)ΓM(p).

For a polynomial pp in two variables with arbitrary real coefficients, denote by p+p+ the sum of its monomials with positive coefficients, and put p−=p+−pp−=p+−p. Thus pp is canonically presented as a difference p+−p−p+−p− of two polynomials with positive coefficients. To obtain the curve defined on logarithmic paper by the equation p(x,y)=0p(x,y)=0, one can construct the graphs Γp+Γp+ and Γp−Γp− for p+p+ and p−p− in the logarithmic space, which are the surfaces defined in the usual Cartesian coordinates by w=ln(p±(eu,ev))w=ln⁡(p±(eu,ev)), and project the intersection Γp+∩Γp−Γp+∩Γp− to the plane of arguments.

For the first approximation of this curve, one may take the broken line, which is the projection of the intersection of the piecewise linear surfaces ΓM(p+)ΓM(p+) and ΓM(p−)ΓM(p−) corresponding to p+p+ and p−p−.

Of course, it may well happen that the broken line does not even resemble the curve. This happens to first approximations. However, it is very appealing to figure out circumstances under which the broken line is a good approximation, for a broken line seems to be much easier to deal with than an algebraic curve.

3.4. Constructing algebraic curves, which are classical from our quantum point of view

Recall that in the logarithmic space the graph of axkylaxkyl is a plane w=ku+lv+lnaw=ku+lv+ln⁡a. It has a normal vector (k,l,−1)(k,l,−1) and intersects the vertical axis at (0,0,lna)(0,0,ln⁡a). Thus if we want to construct a curve of a given degree mm, we have to arrange planes whose normals are fixed: they are (k,l,−1)(k,l,−1) with integers k,lk,l, satisfying inequalities 0≤k,l,k+l≤m0≤k,l,k+l≤m. The only freedom is in moving them up and down.

Consider the pieces of these planes which do not lie under the others. They form a convex piecewise linear surface UU, the graph of the maximum of the linear forms defining our planes. The combinatorial structure of faces in UU depends on the arrangement. Assume that at each vertex of UU exactly three of the planes meet. This is a genericity condition, which can be satisfied by small shifts of the planes.

Divide now the faces of UU arbitrarily into two classes. Denote the union of one of them by U+U+, the union of the other by U−U−. By genericity of the configuration, the common boundary of U+U+ and U−U− is union of disjoint polygonal simple closed curves. It can be easily realized as the intersection of PL-surfaces ΓM(p+)ΓM(p+) and ΓM(p−)ΓM(p−) as above: take for pεpε with ε=±ε=± the sum of monomials corresponding to the planes of faces forming UεUε and put p=p+−p−p=p+−p−.

Consider now for 1≥h≥01≥h≥0 the curve Ch⊂S3hCh⊂Sh3 which is the intersection of the graphs in S3hSh3 of the polynomials D1p+D1p+ and D1p−D1p−. At h=0h=0 this is the intersection of the convex PL-surfaces ΓM(p+)ΓM(p+), ΓM(p−)ΓM(p−). Due to the genericity condition above, this intersection is as transversal as one could wish: at all but a finite number of points the interior part of a face of one of them meets the interior part of a face of the other one, and at the rest of the points an edge of one of the surfaces intersects transversaly the interior of a face of the other surface.

When hh gets positive, the graphs are smoothed, their corners are rounded off. The same happens to their intersection curve. While the graphs are transveral, the intersection curve is deformed isotopically.

Take the curve corresponding to a value of hh such that the transversality is preserved between 0 and this value. The projection to (u,v)(u,v)-plane of ChCh represents an algebraic curve of degree mm on the scaled logarithmic paper and it can be obtained by a small isotopy of the projection of ∂U+∂U+ to the (u,v)(u,v)-plane.

3.5. Is this a patchworking?

A construction, which looks similar, has been known in the topology of real algebraic varieties for about 20 years as patchworking, or Viro’s method. It has been used to construct real algebraic varieties with controlled topology and helped to solve a number of problems. For example, to classify up to isotopy non-singular real plane projective curves of degree 7 [7], [8] and disprove the Ragsdale conjecture [2] on the topology of plane curves formulated [6] as early as in 1906. To the best of my knowledge, the patchworking has never been related to the Litvinov-Maslov quantization.

4. Patchworking real algebraic curves

4.1. The simplest patchworking

Here is a description of a simplified version of patchworking. The simplifications are of the following 3 kinds:

  • •

    we restrict to the case of nonsingular planar curves,

  • •

    we assume that all patches are trinomials, and

  • •

    we consider only the part of the curve contained in the first quadrant (what happens in other quadrants is described soon after).

Initial data. Let mm be a positive integer (it will be the degree of the curve under construction) and ΔΔ be the triangle in ℝ2R2 with vertices (0,0)(0,0), (m,0)(m,0), (0,m)(0,m). Let ττ be a convex triangulation of ΔΔ with vertices having integer coordinates. The convexity of ττ means that there exists a convex piecewise linear function ν:Δ⟶ℝ+ν:Δ⟶R+ which is linear on each triangle of ττ and is not linear on the union of any two triangles of ττ. Let the vertices of ττ be equipped with signs. The sign (plus or minus) at the vertex with coordinates (k,l)(k,l) is denoted by σk,lσk,l.

Construction of the piecewise linear curve. If a triangle of the triangulation ττ has vertices of different signs, draw a midline separating pluses from minuses. Denote by LL the union of these midlines. It is a collection of polygonal lines contained in ΔΔ. The pair (Δ,L)(Δ,L) is called the result of combinatorial patchworking.

Construction of polynomials. Given initial data mm, ΔΔ, ττ and σk,lσk,l as above and a positive convex function νν certifying, as above, that the triangulation ττ is convex. Consider a one-parameter family of polynomials

(3) bt(x,y)=∑\scriptsize(k,l)% runs over\; vertices of τσk,ltν(k,l)xkyl.bt(x,y)=∑\scriptsize(k,l)%runs over\; vertices of τσk,ltν(k,l)xkyl.

The polynomials btbt are called the results of polynomial patchworking.

Patchwork Theorem. Let mm, ΔΔ, ττ, σk,lσk,l and νν be initial data as above. Denote by btbt the polynomials obtained by the polynomial patchworking of these initial data, and by LL the PL-curve in ΔΔ obtained from the same initial data by combinatorial patchworking.

Then for all sufficiently small t>0t>0 the polynomial btbt defines in the first quadrant ℝ2++={(x,y)∈ℝ2∣x,y>0}R++2={(x,y)∈R2∣x,y>0} a curve atat such that the pair (ℝ2++,at)(R++2,at) is homeomorphic to the pair (IntΔ,L∩IntΔ)(Int⁡Δ,L∩Int⁡Δ).

4.2. Patchwork in other quadrants

The Patchwork Theorem applied to bt(−x,y)bt(−x,y), bt(x,−y)bt(x,−y) and bt(−x,−y)bt(−x,−y) gives a similar topological description of the curve defined in the other quadrants by btbt with sufficiently small t>0t>0. The results can be collected in the following natural combinatorial construction.

Construction of the PL-curve. Take copies Δx=sx(Δ)Δx=sx(Δ), Δy=sy(Δ)Δy=sy(Δ), Δxy=s(Δ)Δxy=s(Δ) of ΔΔ, where sx,sysx,sy are reflections with respect to the coordinate axes and s=sx∘sys=sx∘sy. Denote by AΔAΔ the square Δ∪Δx∪Δy∪ΔxyΔ∪Δx∪Δy∪Δxy. Extend the triangulation ττ to a symmetric triangulation of AΔAΔ, and the distribution of signs σi,jσi,j to a distribution at the vertices of the extended triangulation by the following rule: σi,jσεi,δjεiδj=1σi,jσεi,δjεiδj=1, where ε,δ=±1ε,δ=±1. In other words, passing from a vertex to its mirror image with respect to an axis we preserve its sign if the distance from the vertex to the axis is even, and change the sign if the distance is odd.

If a triangle of the triangulation of AΔAΔ has vertices of different signs, select (as above) a midline separating pluses from minuses. Denote by ALAL the union of the selected midlines. It is a collection of polygonal lines contained in AΔAΔ. The pair (AΔ,AL)(AΔ,AL) is called the result of affine combinatorial patchworking. Glue by ss the sides of AΔAΔ. The resulting space PΔPΔ is homeomorphic to the real projective plane ℝP2RP2. Denote by PLPL the image of ALAL in PΔPΔ and call the pair (PΔ,PL)(PΔ,PL) the result of projective combinatorial patchworking.

Addendum to the Patchwork Theorem. Under the assumptions of Patchwork Theorem above, for all sufficiently small t>0t>0 there exist a homeomorphism AΔ→ℝ2AΔ→R2 mapping ALAL onto the the affine curve defined by btbt and a homeomorphism PΔ→ℝP2PΔ→RP2 mapping PLPL onto the projective closure of this affine curve.

4.3. The Simplest Patchworking Coincides With Construction of Section 3.4

The polynomial btbt defined by (3) is presented as b+t−b−tbt+−bt−, where

bεt(x,y)=∑\scriptsize(k,l) runs over the vertices\quad of τ, at which σk,l=ε tν(k,l)xkylbtε(x,y)=∑\scriptsize(k,l) runs over the vertices\quad of τ, at which σk,l=ε tν(k,l)xkyl

Observe that polynomials b±tbt± comprise dequantizing families. Indeed, if we take p(x,y)=∑k,lak,lxkylp(x,y)=∑k,lak,lxkyl with ak,l=e−ν(k,l)ak,l=e−ν(k,l), then for h=−1/lnth=−1/ln⁡t we obtain

ph(x,y)=∑k,la1/hk,lxkyl=∑k,le−ν(k,l)/hxkyl=∑k,leν(k,l)lntxkyl=∑k,ltν(k,l)xkyl.ph(x,y)=∑k,lak,l1/hxkyl=∑k,le−ν(k,l)/hxkyl=∑k,leν(k,l)ln⁡txkyl=∑k,ltν(k,l)xkyl.

Patchwork Theorem deals with sufficiently small positive tt, while hh in a dequantizing family of polynomials was a small positive number approaching 0. This is consistent with our setting h=−1/lnth=−1/ln⁡t.

A monomial ak,lxkyl=e−ν(k,l)xkylak,lxkyl=e−ν(k,l)xkyl is presented in the logarithmic space by the graph of w=ku+lv−ν(k,l)w=ku+lv−ν(k,l). Hence the graph of the maximum of linear forms corresponding to all monomials of p+p+ and p−p− is defined by

(4) w=max{ku+lv−ν(k,l)∣(k,l) runs over vertices of τ}.w=max{ku+lv−ν(k,l)∣(k,l) runs over verticesof τ}.

In (4) we recognize the convex function conjugate to νν. The graph of (4) is a convex PL surface, whose natural stratification is dual to the triangulation ττ of ΔΔ: the face which lies on the plane w=ku+lv−ν(k,l)w=ku+lv−ν(k,l) corresponds to the vertex (k,l)(k,l) of ττ, two such faces meet at an edge in the graph of (4) iff the corresponding vertices are connected with an edge of ττ, three faces meet at a vertex iff the corresponding vertices of ττ belong to a triangle of ττ. In particular, we see that the configuration of planes satisfies the genericity condition of Section 3.4 and planes w=ku+lv−ν(k,l)w=ku+lv−ν(k,l) corresponding to all monomials of b±tbt± show up in the graph of (4) as its faces.

Some of these faces correspond to monomials of b+tbt+, the others to monomials of b−tbt−. The edges which separate the faces of these two kinds constitute a broken line as in Section 3.4. These edges are dual to the edges of ττ which intersect the result LL of the combinatorial patchworking.

Therefore the topology of the projection to the (u,v)(u,v)-plane of the broken line coincides with the topology of LL in ΔΔ. ◻◻

Conclusion

We see that the quantum point of view (or its graphical log paper equivalent) gives a natural explanation to the simplest patchwork construction. The proofs become more conceptual and straight-forward. Of course, similar but slightly more involved quantum explanations can be given to all versions of patchwork.

Let me shortly mention other problems which can be attacked using similar arguments.

First of all, this is the Fewnomial Problem. Although A. G. Khovansky [3] proved that basically all topological characteristics of a real algebraic variety can be estimated in terms of the number of monomials in the equations, the known estimates seem to be far weaker than conjectures. For varieties classical from the quantum point of view a strong estimates are obvious. It is very compelling to estimate how much the topology can be complicated by the quantizing deformations.

There seem to be deep relations between the dequantization of algebraic geometry considered above and the results of I. M. Gelfand, M. M. Kapranov and A. V. Zelevinsky on discriminants [1]. In particular, some monomials in a discriminant are related to intersections of hyperplanes in the dequantized polynomial.

Complex algebraic geometry also deserves a dequantization. Especially relevant may be amoebas introduced in [1].
